content:
Does Python have short-circuit evaluation, or will all expressions in a conditional statement be evaluated?

For instance, would this if statement ever result in an exception, namely the divide by zero error? Or would it short circuit before this could ever happen? 

if b > 0 and a/b == c: 

...

(assuming a, b, and c were assigned values previously in the program)
subject: Does Python have Short-Circuit evaluation?

content:
You can try it yourself in the console! When I ran your example, this is what happened:

>> b = 0
>> b > 0 and 10/b == 0
False

Does this answer your question? If the first statement of the and is evaluated to False, python will not attempt to evaluate the following statement
